conclusion: The graph shows velocity (v) vs time (t) for two objects A and B.
Object A is represented by the straight line segments.
Object B is represented by the curved lines.
Both objects start at the same location and move in the same direction.
The velocity v₀ is the maximum velocity shown on the graph.
Time points are marked as t₁, t₂, t₃, and t₄.
The displacement of an object is the area under the velocity-time curve.
When we want to find the separation between objects, we need to find the difference in their displacements.
From O to t₁: Object A's velocity increases linearly from 0 to some value.
From O to t₁: Object B's velocity decreases from v₀ toward 0.

premise: From O to t₁: Object B is moving faster than A throughout this interval.
conclusion: B is faster than A (separation increasing).
From t₁ to t₂: Object A's velocity continues to increase linearly.
From t₁ to t₂: Object B's velocity continues to decrease.

premise: From t₁ to t₂: Their velocities appear to be equal at some point in this interval, then A becomes faster than B.
conclusion: From t₁ to when their velocities equal: B is faster than A (separation increasing). From when their velocities equal to t₂: A is faster than B (separation decreasing).
From t₂ to t₃: Object A's velocity decreases linearly from v₀ back toward 0.
From t₂ to t₃: Object B's velocity increases from near 0.

premise: From t₂ to t₃: B is slower than A throughout most of this interval.
conclusion: A is faster than B (separation decreasing).
From t₃ to t₄: Object A's velocity continues to decrease linearly to 0.
